feed.title: Against Allowing Quantum Recovery of Bitcoin

entry.title: Against Allowing Quantum Recovery of Bitcoin
entry.summary:
The discussion revolves around the nuanced considerations of using timelocked coins within the Bitcoin network, particularly focusing on the security implications and strategic disadvantages that may arise from such practices. It is highlighted that spending timelocked coins which have not yet had their public keys exposed is deemed relatively safe under current technological capabilities. This safety stems from the understanding that quantum computers, despite their potential, would require significant advancements to decrypt a key and replace-by-fee (RBF) a transaction while it remains unconfirmed in the mempool.
The conversation also delves into the broader implications of employing extremely long time locks on one's digital assets. One critical point raised is the inherent risk associated with locking funds for an extended period, such as more than a year or two. This practice exposes the user to potential edge case protocol weaknesses that might necessitate migrating funds to maintain security. Such a strategy inherently carries a level of discomfort due to the uncertainty and evolving nature of blockchain technology and its surrounding ecosystem.
Furthermore, the dialogue touches upon the economic and governance ramifications of long timelocks. Specifically, it points out that users who lock away their funds for prolonged periods could inadvertently forfeit their ability to participate in vital decision-making processes. This includes being unable to "vote with their feet" in scenarios where contentious chain forks occur, thereby limiting their influence and options within the cryptocurrency community. This aspect underscores the trade-offs between securing one's assets through timelocks and maintaining the flexibility to adapt to the dynamic landscape of blockchain and cryptocurrency developments.
